 4. But neither the United States nor any State shall assume or pay any debt or obligation incurred in aid of insurrection or rebellion against the United States, or any claim for the loss or emancipation of any slave; but all such debts, obligations and claims shall be held illegal and void.
 
 From what I gather this amendment was added in order to disallow debt owed to the Confederate States because of the Civil War. So should this apply to today's current problem? Does Obama have the Power to Ignore the Debt Ceiling in order to pay the bills?

 So does this section place such power in the hands of Congress? It reads to me as if the President does not have such power, so I'm wondering what would happen if The Democrats tried to use this tactic to bypass the GOP on the Debt Ceiling.

 First the debt ceiling is not unconstitutional because it does not prevent the Government from paying its debts, merely prevents the government from going further into debt while paying existing debts. Debt ceiling does not prevent payment of debt per se but it does require spending cuts or tax increases. This is like finding out your uncle is no longer going to slip you an extra 300 bucks a month. You can either get a part time job, scale back on your crack habit, or perhaps look to see if you can spend less per month on pay per view. It is all basic economics really. 
 
 Second, The Dems SHOULD be stay away from this challenge like the plague. it would be political suicide for the party to champion the cause of unlimited spending. This is NOT an argument voters are likely to favor given our present economic condition.
